Receptive to Change
The Academic Council, in a carefully worded
statement this week, has shown its receptiveness
toward change. It has acknowledged for the first time
that there are inadequacies in undergraduate education
here, and has implicitly placed its support behind future
reforms.
The Council's most dramatic (or unexpected)
proposal was that "teaching in all its aspects, from
undergraduate to post-doctoral, as well as research and
scholarship, provides criteria for appointment and
promotion in the University." Although this certainly is
a concession considering Homewood's traditional
emphasis on research, the report carefully ignored the
Student Council's resolution that equal weight be given
to teaching and research.
The A.C. also hedged on the one-professor, one-course
proposal."Some departments do not meet the suggested
standard of one undergraduate course per full-time
faculty member," the Council noted, while placing the
burden of this controversial idea on the advisory Blue
Ribbon Panel. The array of introductory and advanced
undergrad courses was also referred to the BRP. And
whether or not Social Relations should offer an
undergraduate major was left for future Academic
Council meetings.
In short this means that the need for reform in the
undergraduate program, confronted at last, will still
take a long time to implement. Except for freshman
seminars and a few new courses, there probably will not
be a dramatic change in undergrad education next fall.
Maybe the most serious flaw of the Academic Council
report is its myopic view of the student's place in
considering educational reforms. Ironically, the
Council, while expressing sympathy for the plight of
undergrads, has overlooked methods whereby students
could voice their gripes instead of, in desperation
threatening tuition strikes or lawsuits.

A Small Suggestion
Beneath the fervor of the Student Council-Academic
Council hassles over courses and teaching rules, a basic
psychological problem
remains unresolved.
Undergraduates have lost their affiliation with Hopkins.
They go to classes, then return to off-campus
apartments, occasionally stopping at Levering. By and
large, they have no intellectual home, lest it be the
library. They are isolated, and quite rightly angry or
apathetic. Education here has become as academically
stagnant as at those high schools where bells mark off
the allotted time for English, chemistry and history
every day.
Undergraduate lounges in the academic buildings
could go a long way to alleviate this lack of community.
Hopefully, grad students and professors would also
frequent these rooms, fostering informal "education"
and interpersonal contacts. As we envision them, there
would be facilities for establishing a base of operations
away from home--each student with his own cubbyhole,
so to speak.
We urge the Blue Ribbon Panel and its parent
committee, the Academic Council, to carefully examine
this idea. With the new administration building near
completion, Homewood should certainly have enough
net space to spare a few lounge areas. Such rooms were
present in the 1940's and 50's before Homewood became
blindly absorbed with its expansion and, according to
old-timers, were very successful.
As Dr. John White recently told the Faculty
Assembly, "Undergraduates now just emerge on the
first day of class, and then disappear at the end of the
semester. No one seems to know where they come
from."

Receptive to Change
The Academic Council, in a carefully worded
statement this week, has shown its receptiveness
toward change. It has acknowledged for the first time
that there are inadequacies in undergraduate education
here, and has implicitly placed its support behind future
reforms.
The Council's most dramatic (or unexpected)
proposal was that "teaching in all its aspects, from
undergraduate to post-doctoral, as well as research and
scholarship, provides criteria for appointment and
promotion in the University." Although this certainly is
a concession considering Homewood's traditional
emphasis on research, the report carefully ignored the
Student Council's resolution that equal weight be given
to teaching and research.
The A.C. also hedged on the one-professor, one-course
proposal."Some departments do not meet the suggested
standard of one undergraduate course per full-time
faculty member," the Council noted, while placing the
burden of this controversial idea on the advisory Blue
Ribbon Panel. The array of introductory and advanced
undergrad courses was also referred to the BRP. And
whether or not Social Relations should offer an
undergraduate major was left for future Academic
Council meetings.
In short this means that the need for reform in the
undergraduate program, confronted at last, will still
take a long time to implement. Except for freshman
seminars and a few new courses, there probably will not
be a dramatic change in undergrad education next fall.
Maybe the most serious flaw of the Academic Council
report is its myopic view of the student's place in
considering educational reforms. Ironically, the
Council, while expressing sympathy for the plight of
undergrads, has overlooked methods whereby students
could voice their gripes instead of, in desperation
threatening tuition strikes or lawsuits.

A Small Suggestion
Beneath the fervor of the Student Council-Academic
Council hassles over courses and teaching rules, a basic
psychological problem
remains unresolved.
Undergraduates have lost their affiliation with Hopkins.
They go to classes, then return to off-campus
apartments, occasionally stopping at Levering. By and
large, they have no intellectual home, lest it be the
library. They are isolated, and quite rightly angry or
apathetic. Education here has become as academically
stagnant as at those high schools where bells mark off
the allotted time for English, chemistry and history
every day.
Undergraduate lounges in the academic buildings
could go a long way to alleviate this lack of community.
Hopefully, grad students and professors would also
frequent these rooms, fostering informal "education"
and interpersonal contacts. As we envision them, there
would be facilities for establishing a base of operations
away from home--each student with his own cubbyhole,
so to speak.
We urge the Blue Ribbon Panel and its parent
committee, the Academic Council, to carefully examine
this idea. With the new administration building near
completion, Homewood should certainly have enough
net space to spare a few lounge areas. Such rooms were
present in the 1940's and 50's before Homewood became
blindly absorbed with its expansion and, according to
old-timers, were very successful.
As Dr. John White recently told the Faculty
Assembly, "Undergraduates now just emerge on the
first day of class, and then disappear at the end of the
semester. No one seems to know where they come
from."
